form.preferredDefinition: The National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Sleep Patterns and Problems instrument is an interviewer-administered questionnaire which captures routine sleep schedule, sleep deprivation, morningness-eveningness, insomnia, narcolepsy, cataplexy and associated distress.

question.questionText: I am now going to ask you about your usual sleep patterns.
INTERVIEWER: Please tell participant that they should not reveal their diagnosis to you.
Do you normally work (or attend school) during the day and sleep at night? INTERVIEWER: If individual is unemployed and out of school, ask about his/her usual time of activity instead.
What is your normal work (or school) and sleep schedule?

validValue.meaningText: Always works nights, sleeps during the day

question.questionText: What is your normal work (or school) and sleep schedule? Other, Describe
What shift schedule do you most often work?
What shift schedule do you most often work? (Other):
At what time do you usually go to bed: On a workday or school day?
AM or PM
At what time do you usually go to bed: On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)?
AM or PM
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep: On a workday or school day?
About how many minutes does it usually take for you to fall asleep: On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)?
At what time do you usually wake up: On a workday or school day?
AM or PM
At what time do you usually wake up:On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)?
AM or PM
How long does it take for you to become fully awake from regular sleep (i.e., after first opening your eyes in the morning)?
How long does it take for you to become fully awake from regular sleep (i.e., after first opening your eyes in the morning)?
Do you use an alarm clock to wake up in the morning?
Do you have great difficulty waking up in the morning?
Do you often have so much trouble waking up that an alarm clock won't wake you and you have to use other methods to wake up?
Describe
When you wake up in the morning or from a nap, do you feel "out of it" and "confused"?
How long does it take for you to fully awaken? (Minutes)
How long does it take for you to fully awaken? (Hours)
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night: On a workday or school day?
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night: On a workday or school day?
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night: On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)?
How much sleep do you usually get during a typical night: On a nonwork or nonschool day (i.e., weekend)?
Do you usually follow the same sleep schedule (i.e., no more than a 1 hour difference in sleep and wake times) on both work/school and nonwork/school days? (or school days and weekends)
How many hours of sleep per night do you think you need to feel fully rested the next day?
Do you feel awake and refreshed after sleeping?
How often do you remember your dreams? That is, dreams that occur during your regular sleep and not while napping
How often do you take naps?
At what time(s) of the day do you usually take naps? INTERVIEWER: List up to 3 time(s) of the day.
AM or PM
At what time(s) of the day do you usually take naps?
AM or PM
At what time(s) of the day do you usually take naps?
AM or PM
How many hours and minutes of sleep do you usually get when you take a nap?
How many hours and minutes of sleep do you usually get when you take a nap?
Do you have great difficulty waking up from naps?
How often do you dream when you nap?
Are these dreams very intense, detailed and vivid, like watching a movie?
How difficult is it for you to adapt to a sleep loss of 3 hours or more (i.e. sleeping 3 or more hours less than you normally do the night before)?

INTERVIEWER: For the questions below, first determine whether sleep loss affects these factors. If there is a change following sleep loss,select whether there is an improvement or a worsening, or an increase or decrease.
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to. your mood (being sadder or happier)?
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to. your mood (being sadder or happier)?
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to.your tendency to be irritable?
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to. your tendency to be irritable? (If yes, How?)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your ability to get your work done?
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to...? your ability to get your work done? (If yes, How?)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to how much you eat?
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to how much you eat? (If yes, How?)
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your desire for chocolate or sweets?
Does this loss of sleep affect you the next day with respect to your desire for chocolate or sweets? (If yes, How?)
How quickly after this loss of sleep, do you return to your usual self if you are allowed to sleep as much as you like?
Do you prefer to keep a regular sleep schedule (i.e. one that does not change much from one night to the next)?
If you do not keep your regular sleep schedule, how much do you feel off (i.e. not your regular self) the next day?"
When you are traveling EAST by air and you cross over several time zones, how quickly do you return to your usual sleeping pattern?
What about when you are traveling WEST by air over several time zones?
Do you consider yourself to be a morning person (early bird) an evening person (night owl) or neither?
How strong is your preference?
INTERVIEWER: Does respondent consistently fall asleep very late (i.e., 12 a.m. or later) at night AND characterize him/herself as a night owl" with a "strong preference"?"

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): ...at what time do you usually go to sleep (i.e. feel sleepy and ready to go to bed)?
AM or PM
When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): ...at what time do you usually wake up
AM or PM

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): ...are these usual sleep and wake times always about the same (i.e. each day during a week of vacation)?

When you do not have to maintain a strict schedule (i.e. not dictated by strict work or school schedules, as while on vacation or not working): ...do you wake up on your own (i.e., without an alarm or other assistance)?
Have you ever tried to force yourself to fall asleep at an (earlier) time than your usual bedtime?
When you tried to shift your sleep schedule to an earlier bedtime (at least 1 to 2 hours earlier), did you have difficulty falling asleep?
Do attempts to change your sleep/wake schedule tend to make your sleeping difficulties worse?
During the past year, what was the longest period of time that you had these sleeping problems on most nights?
During the past year, what was the longest period of time that you had these sleeping problems on most nights?
During the past year, what was the longest period of time that you had these sleeping problems on most nights?
How old were you when you first began going to sleep very late without being able to adjust your schedule when you tried?
How old were you the last time you experienced these problems?
Do you currently experience these problems?
Please look at this scale from 0 to 10, where 0 means no distress/impairment and 10 means very severe problems.
How much have your late bedtime and inability to adjust your schedule upset or distressed you?
What number describes how much this eveningness tendency has affected your social life and/or relationships with your friends?
What number describes how much this eveningness tendency has affected your relationships with family members?
What number describes how much this eveningness tendency has affected your performance in school/work or your relationships with your coworkers, employers, teachers or classmates?
Have you ever had frequent problems getting to sleep at the beginning of the night which has negatively affected how you function during the following day?
Have you ever had frequent problems staying asleep at night which has negatively affected how you function during the following day?
Have you ever had frequent problems falling back to sleep after waking in the middle of the nigh which has negatively affected how you function during the following day?
In the past year, have you had difficulty getting to sleep?
In the past year, have you awakened during the night and had a hard time getting back to sleep?
In the past year, have you awakened too early in the morning and couldn't get back to sleep?
What was the longest period of time you had sleeping problems (such as those described above) on most nights during the past year? (weeks)
What was the longest period of time you had sleeping problems (such as those described above) on most nights during the past year? (months)
What was the longest period of time you had sleeping problems (such as those described above) on most nights during the past year?(years)
INTERVIEWER: If respondent endorses less than one month of sleeping problems, SKIP to NarcolepsyCataplexy section.
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Attention, concentration or memory problems?
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Errors or accidents at work or while driving?
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Social problems or poor work/school performance?
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Fatigue?
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Sleepiness?
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Feeling tense/muscle tension?
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Headaches?
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Gastrointestinal symptoms (e.g. upset stomach, nervous stomach)?
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Mood changes/problems or irritability?

Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: A lack of motivation or energy to do things (manifested as e.g. procrastination or lack of initiative)?
Do you experience any of the following during the daytime due to your difficulties falling asleep or staying asleep at night: Concerns or worries about sleep?
Do you do any of the following during the night when you cannot fall asleep, do you: Experience frustration, tension and/or anxiety over not being able to go to sleep?
Do you do any of the following during the night when you cannot fall asleep, do you: Look at the clock frequently to see how long you have not been able to fall asleep?

When you are NOT sleeping in your usual bed (e.g. in a hotel room while on vacation, or on your couch watching television), do you still have problems initially getting to sleep, staying asleep, or falling back to sleep after waking up during the night?

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...caffeine or other stimulant use?

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...other drugs or medications?
Specify
Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following? ...changing schedule?
Specify

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...noisy or uncomfortable surroundings?
Specify

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...stress or major life event?
Specify

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...other disturbances (i.e. children, pets, etc.)?
Specify

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...an emotional or mental condition?
Specify

Does your difficulty with insomnia occur at the same time as any of the following events or conditions (i.e. is the insomnia associated temporally with any of the following)? ...other medical condition?
Specify
Do you ever have trouble falling asleep or staying asleep, when there seems to be no cause or explanation for it?
Specify
Has your difficulty with sleeping occurred or worsened during any of the following conditions... pregnancy?
Has your difficulty with sleeping occurred or worsened during any of the following conditions... menopause? (ask for women over 35)
Has your difficulty with sleeping occurred or worsened during any of the following conditions... just before (a few days) menstruation?
Has your difficulty with sleeping occurred or worsened during any of the following conditions... menstruation?
How many separate times in your life have you had difficulty getting to sleep, staying asleep or falling back to sleep after waking up during the night (for at least one month)?
How old were you when you first experienced this kind of difficulty with sleeping (for at least one month)?
How old were you the last time you experienced this insomnia (for at least one month)?
Do you currently experience insomnia?
How frequently do you experience insomnia? (Times per week)
Please look at this scale from 0 to 10, where 0 means no distress/impairment and 10 means very severe problems.
How much does your insomnia (sleep difficulties) upset or distress you?
What number describes how much your insomnia has affected your social life or relationships with your friends?
What number describes how much your insomnia has affected your relationships with family members?
What number describes how much your insomnia has affected your performance in school/work or your relationships with your coworkers, employers, teachers or classmates?
A. Daytime Sleepiness
Do you feel so sleepy during the day that it interrupts your normal activities such as driving, reading, or concentrating at work or school, even when you have had enough sleep the night before?
How often do you feel this way? (Times per Day)
How often do you feel this way? (Times per Week)
How often do you feel this way? (Times per Month)
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)?
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)?
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)?
During the daytime, do you experience an overwhelming desire to go to sleep so overwhelming that you cannot resist?
How often does this overwhelming desire to go to sleep occur? (Times per Day)
How often does this overwhelming desire to go to sleep occur? (Times per Week)
How often does this overwhelming desire to go to sleep occur? (Times per Month)
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)?
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)?
What is the longest period of time that you have felt this way (on most days)?
When you do doze off during the day and take a nap, do you find this sleep refreshing?
When you do doze off during the day and take a nap, do you find this sleep refreshing? Describe
Do you feel that you are sleepier than other people your age?
B. Cataplexy
Do you ever experience periods of muscle weakness, loss of muscle strength or limp muscles in any part of your body (e.g. in the legs or face) during the following situations: ...when you laugh?
Do you ever experience periods of muscle weakness, loss of muscle strength or limp muscles in any part of your body (e.g. in the legs or face) during the following situations: ...when you are angry?

Do you ever experience periods of muscle weakness, loss of muscle strength or limp muscles in any part of your body (e.g. in the legs or face) during the following situations: ...when you hear or tell a joke?
Have you ever been told that you act out" your dreams?"
How often does this happen (weeks)?
How often does this happen (months)?
How often does this happen (years)?
Do you ever move so much during your sleep that you accidentally hit your bed partner (if any) or hurt yourself?
Do you have any memory of these event(s)?
Does moving at night disrupt your sleep? (i.e. wake you up at night)
During what part of the night do these events most often occur?

protocol.preferredDefinition: The National Institute of Mental Health (NIMH) Sleep Patterns and Problems instrument is an interviewer-administered questionnaire which captures routine sleep schedule, sleep deprivation, morningness-eveningness, insomnia, narcolepsy, cataplexy and associated distress.

form.longName: PhenX Global Mental Status Screener Adult - PX130701
form.preferredDefinition: The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA©) is a screening instrument for mild cognitive impairment and more severe cognitive deficits. It is an interviewer-administered questionnaire in which the respondent performs certain tasks, such as drawing and counting, to assess various cognitive domains, such as attention, memory, orientation, language, conceptual thinking and planning.

question.questionText: Please consult www.mocatest.org for permission and requirements to use the MoCA test.
IMAGE
Please draw a line, going from a number to a letter in ascending order. Begin here [point to (1)] and draw a line from 1 then to A then to 2 and so on. End here [point to (E)].",0
Copy this drawing as accurately as you can, in the space below
Draw a clock. Put in all the numbers and set the time to 10 after 11.
Tell me the name this animal
Tell me the name this animal
Tell me the name this animal

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Face

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Velvet

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Church

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Daisy

This is a memory test. I am going to read a list of words that you will have to remember now and later on. Listen carefully. When I am through, tell me as many words as you can remember. It doesn't matter in what order you say them. Red
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Face
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Velvet
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Church
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Daisy
I am going to read the same list for a second time. Try to remember and tell me as many words as you can, including words you said the first time. Red
I am going to say some numbers and when I am through, repeat them to me exactly as I said them. 2,1,8,5,4
Now I am going to say some more numbers, but when I am through you must repeat them to me the in the backwards order. 7,4,2

I am going to read a sequence of letters. Every time I say the letter A, tap your hand once. If I say a different letter, do not tap your hand. F,B,A,C,M,N,A,A,J,K,L,B,A,F,A,K,D,E,A,A,A,J,A,M,O,F,A,A,B
Now, I will ask you to count by subtracting seven from 100, and then, keep subtracting seven from your answer until I tell you to stop.
I am going to read you, a sentence. Repeat it after me, exactly as I say it [pause]: I only know that John is the one to help today.
Now I am going to read you another sentence. Repeat it after me, exactly as I say it [pause]: The cat always hid under the couch when dogs were in the room.

Tell me as many words as you can think of that begin with a certain letter of the alphabet that I will tell you in a moment. You can sav any kind of word you want, except for proper nouns (like Bob or Boston), numbers, or words that begin with the same sound but have a different suffix, for example, love, lover, loving. I will tell you to stop after one minute. Are you ready? [Pause] Now, tell me as many words as you can think of that begin with the letter F. [time for 60 sec]. Stop.
Now, tell me how a train and a bicycle are alike.
Now tell me how a ruler and a watch are alike.

"I read some words to you earlier, which I asked you to remember. Tell me as many of those words as you can remember." Make a check mark (?) for each of the words correctly recalled spontaneously without any cues, in the allocated space. Scoring: Allocate 1 point for each word recalled freely without any cues.
Tell me the date today
If subject does not give a complete date, then: "Tell me the [year, month, exact data, and day of the week["
Tell me the name of this place, and which city it is in.

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Montreal Cognitive Assessment (MoCA©) is a screening instrument for mild cognitive impairment and more severe cognitive deficits. It is an interviewer-administered questionnaire in which the respondent performs certain tasks, such as drawing and counting, to assess various cognitive domains, such as attention, memory, orientation, language, conceptual thinking and planning.

form.longName: PhenX Signs Of Essential Tremor - PX131301
form.preferredDefinition: The Washington Heights-Inwood Genetic Study of Essential Tremor (WHIGET) Tremor Rating Scale is a 23-item videotaped examination that assesses rest, postural, and kinetic tremor severity. Rated tasks include arm extension, pouring water between cups, drinking from a spoon, drinking from a cup, drawing Archimedes spirals, and touching a finger to the nose. The protocol includes scoring and classification instructions. A teaching videotape is also available to aid in training raters.

question.questionText: While the subject is seated, please observe:
Hands resting in lap for 15 s

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Arms held at 90 degrees for 15 s (arm sustention)

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Arms held in wing position for 15 s

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Pouring water from one cup to another (cups should be standard size and at least three quarters filled 8 transfers)

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Bring a spoon of water from lap level up to mouth and back again repeat 7 additional times

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Drinking water from a full glass repeat 7 times with each hand

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Fingernosefinger on right 8 times

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Fingernosefinger on left 8 times

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Open and close right hand 10 times

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Open and close left hand 10 times

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Alternatively pronate and supinate right hand 10 times

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Alternatively pronate and supinate left hand 10 times

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Tap right foot 10 times

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Tap left foot 10 times

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Jaw at rest for 5 s

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Mouth open for 5 s

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Sustained phonation: first "AAA" for 10 s then "EEE"

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: Head while patient is seated for 10 s

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: The examiner will test the passive tone of each arm and leg and comment on this on the videotape.
Drawing 2 Archimedes spirals with each hand (subject should make at least 6 full circular motions).

validValue.meaningText: low-amplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor
tremor is of moderate amplitude (1-2 cm) and usually present; it is clearly oscillatory
large-amplitude (>2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper

question.questionText: While the subject is standing, please observe:
Hands hanging at sides for 10 s videotape legs too.
Walking 20 ft and turning
Tandem gait for 10 steps
Dominant Hand

Scoring: Criteria for ET: 1. On examination, a +2 postural tremor of at least 1 arm (a head tremor may also be present, but is insufficient for the diagnosis) 2. On examination, there must be a. a +2 kinetic tremor during at least 4 tasks or b. a +2 kinetic tremor on 1 task and a +3 kinetic tremor on a second task tasks include: pouring water, using a spoon to drink water, drinking water, fingertonose, and drawing a spiral 3. If on examination the tremor is present in the dominant hand, then by report it must interfere with at least 1 activity of daily living (eating, drinking, writing, use of hands) if on examination, the tremor is not present in the dominant hand, this criterion is irrelevant. 4. Medications, hyperthyroidism, alcohol, or dystonia are not potential etiologic factors 5. Not psychogenic (bizarre features, inconsistent in character, changing, subject is distractable, other psychiatric features on examination) Criteria for probable ET (1 and 35 must be true also, either 2a or 2b must be true): 1. On examination, a +2 postural tremor of arms may or may not be present 2. (a) Same as 2 above (b) Head tremor is present on examination 3. Tremor in the dominant hand may or may not interfere with at least 1 daily activity 4. Medications, hyperthyroidism, dystonia, or alcohol are not potential etiologic factors 5. Not psychogenic Criteria for possible ET: 1. On examination, a +2 kinetic tremor must be present on 3 tasks 2. No other stipulations Tremor Ratings (0 to +3): 0 = no visible tremor +1 = lowamplitude/barely perceivable tremor or intermittent tremor +2 = tremor is of moderate amplitude (12 cm) and usually present it is clearly oscillatory +3 = largeamplitude (more then 2 cm), violent, jerky tremor resulting in difficulty completing the task due to spilling or inability to hold a pen to paper. Note from the Neurology Working Group: Please see Louis (2001) TRUNCATED

protocol.preferredDefinition: The Washington Heights-Inwood Genetic Study of Essential Tremor (WHIGET) Tremor Rating Scale is a 23-item videotaped examination that assesses rest, postural, and kinetic tremor severity. Rated tasks include arm extension, pouring water between cups, drinking from a spoon, drinking from a cup, drawing Archimedes spirals, and touching a finger to the nose. The protocol includes scoring and classification instructions. A teaching videotape is also available to aid in training raters.
